results.text: You have so many dates and names and places swimming in your mind you sometimes get things mixed up. You have disadvantage on your next History check.

You’re usually more careful when handling ancient artifacts, but this time you’re a little ham-fisted. You either snap a piece off of the artifact, break the spine of the book, or otherwise irreparably tear the ancient scroll you are currently holding.

Your source material (which may be considered dubious in some academic circles) attributes this carving, passage, or book to a completely different time period and uses a different dialect to translate it. You recall an incorrect name, date, or important location as a result, though you believe it to be true.
You’re sure this historical tidbit is the key to a breakthrough in your adventures, but really it’s just a dead end. You lose a day of travel or downtime.
You incorrectly trace a person’s lineage back through the wrong records. You misattribute an important or scandalous anecdote to the family tree of someone you are familiar with.
You clearly don’t know as much as you thought you do. You temporarily lose an expertise die on History checks for the next 24 hours.
